review_title: FRE not meant for the over ambitious
pros:
- Flexibility with schedule 
- Stress free environment, no sense of urgency to get anything completed 
- Generous Leave package
- Wonderful/nice people

FRE a great place to work if you have personal obligations outside of work requiring you to have a non-demanding/flexible work schedule. If you are interested in going back to school, or have children, family member that requires a huge time commitment, then FRE is a great place to work. If your goal is to advance professionally, be challenged or make an impact then I would not recommend FRE.
cons:
- General lack of professionalism 
- No clear direction on company strategy 
- Peer pressure not to over achieve
- No growth opportunity 

To say the least, the company is in great flux as the fate of the GSE’s are being determined on the hill. This leaves no direction or motivation to employees to meet deadlines, achieve goals or make an impact. Many directors/senior managers, have been promoted due to putting their “time in” (i.e. working in the same role for over 10 years) and not for their abilities. Most people are just waiting it out for a generous retirement and/or compensation package to be offered.
Advice to Management
- Push the adminstration to make a decision on your fate. Untill then save your energy on the mult re-orgs and strategies.

- Push the adminstration to make a decision on your fate. Untill then save your energy on the mult re-orgs and strategies.

pros: I'm fairly compensated for the work that I do, and the benefits package is in some ways better than average. The people that I work with are nice people.
cons:
Senior management keeps saying that it wants the company to become more efficient and more effective, yet continues to ignore the management practices that would do just that. The company has a strong culture of "group think" masquerading as "consensus". Every attempt at promoting change is met with a demand by management that dozens of stakeholders are included in the decision-making, rather than permitting subject matter experts to structure solutions and make decisions, virtually guaranteeing a disappointing result. One might conclude that to senior management, the appearance of progress is more important than actual progress.
Advice to Management
Stop insisting on a "kumbaya" every time a decision needs to be taken or a process change is contemplated. Allow people who are recognized experts in that field or discipline to structure solutions, and then MANDATE usage.
Helpful (2
advice_to_mgmt: Stop insisting on a "kumbaya" every time a decision needs to be taken or a process change is contemplated. Allow people who are recognized experts in that field or discipline to structure solutions, and then MANDATE usage.

review_title: OK Place to work but very little upward mobility.
pros: The culture is very relaxed and friendly. There are alot of smart people at Freddie that are very happy to help and answer your questions. Great for families and people with kids because of the flexible work arrangements. Our current management seems to be very competent.
cons:
There is very little upward mobility. A large portion of the organization is stuck in the middle management level which makes it very difficult for young analyst/professions to advance quickly. The pay is not very competitive compared to the other companies in the area. Not a place for young, ambitions a-types. There are many untapped talents that are being underutilized.
Advice to Management
Work harder to create a pipeline for young talent to advance uo through the ranks. The older, slower people who are clogging up the middle and are not willing to accept change are slowing down the organization.

review_title: IT division is in shambles... not the company it used to be
pros: Though it's changed much recently, there are plenty of great colleagues for the most part below the director level and still offers good/great benefits/perks.
cons:
Since the conservatorship, much confusion exists within the rank and file as to the true 'mission' of the organization due to conflicting messages from the senior management. Most spout the public policy arm of the Fed gov't message in official capacity but some spout a yearning for the return to the glory days of obscene profiteering in private. Recent influx of ex-Wall Street executives has had adverse affects in morale, especially within IT division.
Advice to Management
Get all the senior management folx in synch with respect to the strategic goal/vision. Is it to become public entity once again, is it to serve the public policy of the Fed Gov't or is it to ensure victory over the arch nemesis Fannie Mae in what many consider to eventual end of the conservatorship... merging of the 2 companies.

pros: The people are very nice and the physical work environments are generally good, except for contractors who labor in cramped rooms. Benefits and salary are competative. Formalized training is good. There is much to be done and the company is hiring.
cons:
The IT environment is high pressure to the extreme with no regard for work life balance. Employees regularly work long hours and over weekends and holidays just to keep up with their own work. People show up sick for the same reason which spreads illness (remote work is discouraged). Collaboration tools such as NetMeeting are not used so people must walk between buildings (outside) to attend face to face meetings. This is a big time waster. Tools and processes are outdated and excessively bureaucratic.
Advice to Management
Take a good look at the costs incurred by lack of collaboration tools. Substantially trim and improve the SDLC and PMLC processes so that they are manageable for users to learn and utilize. Understand that working people to death leads to a lot of corner-cutting, poor decisions, hiding of issues, and mismanaged efforts. You reap what you sow.

review_title: Really think about it before you accept...
pros: Salary and possible signing bonus (now I know why they thew a lot of money at me). People in many parts of the organization are truly dedicated to the mission, many long timers.
cons:
First level managers are geared towards being individual contributors first and then managing their direct reports is far down the list. This may be all well and good as it means you will be self-managed, but given the complexity of the organization (communication, technology, processes/procedures, politics, etc.) it could make your first months or year very, very difficult. Big picture - the future of the GSE's is anything but stable as only the Gods know what the future holds for Fannie and Freddie...weigh the risks.
Advice to Management
Do not promote individuals to managers if they're better suited to being indivdual contributors, structure the departments/divisions accordingly so these people can advance w/o becoming a "manager".
Helpful (1
advice_to_mgmt: Do not promote individuals to managers if they're better suited to being indivdual contributors, structure the departments/divisions accordingly so these people can advance w/o becoming a "manager".

review_title: Good company but very narrowly focused jobs
pros:
It has a great cafeteria, facilities (doctor on site, gym, ATMs), and general benefits plan.
The work/life balance is fair. Freddie is good about rewarding high performance. If you are rated high during annual review, your bonus with reflect so. It also has a very nice and diverse atmosphere of colleagues.
cons:
Management is terrible. All decisions have to go through the entire food chain of managers so even little decisions take months and months to resolve, if at all. 
One of my biggest disappointments about working here so how pigeon-holed you are in a job. The roles are very narrow and very focused but the company doesn't spend or want to waste time training you to learn big picture issues. 
The technology is the very worst I've ever seen. A lot of the systems were built in the 80s but the company either halts projects to update them or does not want to spend the money. 
It's hard to move to a different section of the company, even internally.
Advice to Management
Be more decisive and be quicker with changes. Adapting is not something Freddie does well. Be more proactive instead of reactive. Waiting for the problems to blow up before fixing them leads to headaches for everyone.
Helpfu
advice_to_mgmt:

cons:
They don't respect employees. They say they promote work/life balance but in reality it doesn't happen. They don't appreciate the long tenured employee as they have laid off a substantial number of employees who were there more than 20 years but they keep hiring "college hires" at a cheaper salary but they don't know the business.

You need to be honest with employees and not treat them like they are idiots or like they don't matter.

pros: There is a great dedication to the community. There are a lot of options for ongoing learning and you will feel supported from your supervisors and the team around you. There are lots of times to share ideas with supervisors who are usually open to ideas. The culture embodies empowerment although it is obvious that some employees are not ready for change. The hours offer a work life balance and the employee sponsored perks are also attractive. Team work here is one of the best things that is offered and it is great to know that you have others who work as hard as you do.
cons:
Communication can be improved but the monthly newsletters are always good. There is often great recognition of employee achievements listed in the newsletter but other than that, there is not a lot of recognition throughout the company. I would also like to see more mentoring, especially for interns who may not have time to attend the networking groups. More diversity would also be helpful and Freddie Mac may want to consider being more proactiv in bring about change that includes more women and minorities throughout the company. Feedback should be pursued by the employee as supervisors are not always on top of it.

Keep up the good work

review_title: Interesting if you like a challenge
pros:
The opportunity to create a new Freddie Mac Information Technology from the ground up. There are clear opportunities for advancement and recognition for individuals who can identify fully sustainable solutions to complex information technology issues. The ability to take an idea of a solution to the problem and in most cases having that idea heard, discussed, and debated fairly.

Overall the mission of Freddie Mac (despite the recent troubles) still serves as an important one in this country. I believe providing a fair market for home ownership in this country is an excellent mission and one that you can be proud of supporting.
cons:
The lack of clear direction. The drive to put out fires in the lawn when the house is burning down. The long hours and expectations on individuals and teams that have been working non-stop and full steam for two plus years in full remediation mode.
Advice to Management
Understand that sometimes the only sustainable solution to the issue is to step back and identify and tackle the root problem.

review_title: Good place to work with a lot of internal problems.
pros: Great benefits and competitive salaries. Good location, great gym and cafeteria.
cons:
Incopotenet senior management, too many middle-managers and directors with no direct reports, but who have huge, over $120K, salaries. The review process is very ineffective and many incopetent managers simply unable to give good feedback or criticize constructively. The IT environment is pityful: millions of dollars were wasted on project that were later written off, unbeleivable budgets and consultant spending for IT projects and system implementations which are then purged.

pros: Nice office environment, gym, wonderful cafeteria, indoor free parking. Job security in the midst of a crazy mortgage industry environment. The benefits package is excellent.
cons:
60-80 hour workweek with no overtime paid. No time for any personal life. Work time lost during vacation or sick leave must be made up on personal time. Everyone is constantly stressed out and dragging work home. Quotas are everything and management does not care what you have to do to meet them. The quotas keep getting higher for the same number of hours and the bonus plan keeps getting smaller. The decisionmakers are taking advantage of the job shortage and treating current employees like sweat-shop slaves.
Advice to Management
Allow prorated quotas for months when vacation is taken.

advice_to_mgmt: Allow prorated quotas for months when vacation is taken.

review_title: Young? Ambitious? Talented? This isn't the place for you.
pros:
Benefits:
Home benefit
Education
Standard 401k match (3% given 6% contribution)
Friendly "government-like" atmosphere
cons:
Not a true financial service firm (not the same mentality)
Passive staff + mediocre talent = bureaucracy
Slow career advancement. They pigeonhole you. Once you see the light, it's already too late. You're stuck for the long haul.
The place is filled with middle management. Many managers don't actually manage employees. They essentially perform the same function that entry level associates encounter, yet their salaries are bloated.
Consultants-galore. I've never seen so many at one firm before. You'll go to meetings with a 10 consultant to 1 freddie employee ratio. Consultants are hired to repeat the work of other consultants. 
Young, talented people leave immediately.
Advice to Management
Pay your employees. Recruit from better programs.
Helpful (1

pros: The public mission and work / life balance. The company has a great brand and culture. This is largely created by its public mission of providing liquidity to the mortgage market and promoting affordable housing. I joined Freddie Mac because of this appeal. Also, the company provides good benefits and training.
cons:
The combination of an inept, overpaid senior management team and a heavily regulated and audited control environment make Freddie Mac one of the most difficult places to innovate. Bureaucracy is a fact of life, and many executives and managers are unwilling to change the company because transformation threatens their status quo.
Advice to Management
Freddie Mac should get serious about its public mission. The split personality created by being a shareholder-owned enterprise with a social mission will go away with nationalization.
Helpful (2
advice_to_mgmt: Freddie Mac should get serious about its public mission. The split personality created by being a shareholder-owned enterprise with a social mission will go away with nationalization.

review_title: Freddie Mac -- Good, but not ideal
pros: In my opinion, the best reason to work at Freddie Mac is the mission -- Making home possible. Freddie Mac genuinely tries to serve this mission as best as possible, and it makes it a good place to work. Despite its faults (and there are many) at the end of the day you can feel good about what you're doing when you leave work. There are not many places where this is the case. Other reasons to work for Freddie Mac are the benefits and work-life balance. The compensation is fair considering the 7.75 hour work day Freddie Mac has.
cons:
Freddie Mac is a very lazy atmosphere as an institution. The average workday is only 7.75 hours.. if you walk through the building on a Friday afternoon at 3pm, at least half the place will be empty. Simply put, people work, but not as hard as they should. Freddie Mac has a laid back atmosphere that borders on lazy.

Morale is also generally low as the institution lacks good senior leaders. At times it is directionless and seems to not know where it wants to go. There is no long term vision from senior management... and that is very apparent.
Advice to Management
Develop a long term vision.
Helpfu
advice_to_mgmt:
Develop a long term vision.
Helpfu

employee_status: Marketing Communications Manager in McLean, VA
review_title: Good benefits and compensation but attracts the corporate Dilbert types instead of the best of the industry.
pros: Benefits, compensation and work life balance are good reasons to work at Freddie Mac. Most employees work a nine to five day and the building goes pretty quiet after 5 pm every day. There are some nice perks, such as good food service, decent snacks shops in each building, complete with Starbucks. There is also an on site health clinic and a gym, which is a great perk.
cons:
Beuracratic. Inneficient. Attracts corporate Dilbert types instead of the best of the industry. There are a lot of people working here who have been her for many years and have made careers out of Freddie so they know how to work the system and get away with doing the minumum. The company has gone through two or three financial crisis' by now so things don't always seem as stable as they could be.
Advice to Management
Provide a better sense of stability for investors and employees.
Helpful (1
advice_to_mgmt: Provide a better sense of stability for investors and employees.

review_title: Don't buy a house for yourself anytime soon
pros: You get into the heart of the mortgage market, and learn a ton on how the capital market works. There is also much flexibility in career movements in within as long as you stay in each job for a year minimum. Work life balance is good in most departments. Good corporate supports on training and personal development.
cons:
The company's future is very unclear, not even in the hands of the management or investors. Nobody knows what's going to happen to the company 6 months from now, not to mention long term career planning. Compensation is going to be tight. Don't plan on buying a house for yourself soon if you work there.
Advice to Management
Communication. Share with employees information on the long term picture whenever possible so that employees will know if they have a future here.

review_title: Great benefits but a political and uncertain environment
pros: The benefits are fantastic; employees can purchase extra vacation up to five weeks, but those who prefer the minimum two weeks can actually give days back for more money. In addition, the company offers a wide variety of health plans, life insurance, and disability insurance. Another great reason to work at Freddie Mac is that people who are smart and willing to work hard will likely find themselves really standing apart from the crowd and being rewarded.
cons:
There are a number of downsides. The people can be complacent and passive-aggressive. Depending on the area of the company you work in, there is a lot of turf protection and office politics. The recent government intervention makes the future uncertain.
Advice to Management
Invest heavily in making IT and business processes simpler and less complex. Make the organization much flatter and continue differentiating more between top and low performers.
Helpfu
advice_to_mgmt:
Invest heavily in making IT and business processes simpler and less complex. Make the organization much flatter and continue differentiating more between top and low performers.

cons:
Pay for performance is not really working. It has been applied to Pay more for your best friend than to your best performer.

Do not lie to your employees. We are intelligent and willing to take sacrifices for the success this Company and its true Mission; but Do not talk about Pay for Performance or Reduction of G&A to meet objectives. Objectives to create shareholder value brought us here and only the closest friends of a manager get the highest rates regardless of performance. By the way I am a high performer well rated.

pros: If you can survive inevitable rounds of downsizing, you may end up with a government job. Political posturing is very important and can be used to cover any flaw. The atmosphere is surprisingly laid back despite the ramifications of bad debt being felt outside the company. Since priorities are askew, accountability is non-existent allowing people to settle in to a virtual slumber during the workday.
cons:

employee_status: Operation Risk Analyst in McLean, VA
review_title: Good place to start career but better opportunities elsewhere might be available
pros: The company offers flexibility to its employees to manage their work/life balance. For example, the option to work from home is available for some employees. Benefits are very good (401(k), pension plan, health/vision/dental/life are offered to full-time employees), campus is beautiful (and has two on-site gyms and a general doctor's office). People are cordial, helpful and very bright (most managers hold a masters degree or above, and have a significant amount of experience under their resumes). You will learn a lot about fixed income securities very fast. Managers are very accessible and helpful. The company is very diverse and encourages multiculturalism.
cons:
Salaries are below what other financial services firms offer. Not very exciting for young professionals
Advice to Management
Offer more guidance to new hires and increase compensation to keep workers motivated.
